name.text: 10.2.15 (Example of finding normal to a curve)

questiontext.text:
Example

Find the equation of the normal to the curve \(y = \frac{8}{\sqrt{x}}\) at the point where \(x = 4\).

Solution

When \(x = 4\), \(y = \frac{8}{\sqrt{4}} = \frac{8}{2} = 4\). Thus the point where the curve intersects the normal is \((4,4)\).

Now, \(f(x) = 8x^{1/2}\), thus \(f'(x) = -4x^{-3/2}\) and so \(f'(4) = -4 \cdot 4^{-3/2} = -\frac{1}{2}\).

Therefore the gradient of the normal at the point \((4,4)\) is given by \[ -\frac{1}{f'(4)} = -\frac{1}{-1/2} = 2. \]

So, using the formula above, the equation of the normal is \[ y = 2(x - 4) + 4 \implies y = 2x -4. \]
